title: AB 1847
content: The people of California enact the following. The Legislature amended Section 19851 of the Revenue and Taxation Code to address the low participation rate in the federal Earned Income Tax Credit program. In 2015, California authorized a state EITC to help the poorest working Californians. In 2015, California authorized a state EITC to amplify the poverty-reducing effects of the federal EITC for the poorest working Californians by providing information on claiming credits on federal and state income tax returns. The act aims to provide cost-effective assistance to eligible taxpayers through notices from employers and state agencies, ensuring Californians claim both federal and state EITC. Definitions for terms like "employer," "employee," and "Federal EITC" are clarified in the Revenue and Taxation Code. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to the federal and California earned income tax credits, as well as state departments and agencies that serve eligible individuals. The State Department of Education, Employment Development Department, and State Department of Health Care Services provide programs such as free or reduced-price meals, California Unemployment Insurance, and the Medi-Cal program. Employers are required to notify employees about eligibility for federal and California EITC when providing annual wage summaries. State departments and agencies must inform program recipients annually about potential eligibility for federal and California EITC, either between January and April or during regular contact. Indirect communication through other entities serving eligible individuals is also encouraged. State departments and agencies are encouraged to inform program recipients annually about potential eligibility for federal and California EITC through indirect communication with other entities serving eligible individuals. They should develop effective methods to provide notice containing the same language as specified in Section 19854. The employer must provide notification directly to the employee or by mail, including instructions on obtaining IRS and Franchise Tax Board notices and information on California EITC. Posting notices on bulletin boards or sending through office mail does not satisfy the requirement, but is encouraged for informing all employees about federal and California EITC. The employer must provide direct notification to employees about the availability of federal and California EITC. Posting notices on bulletin boards or sending through office mail is encouraged but does not fulfill the requirement. Amendments to this section apply to notices provided after the effective date of the act. Based on your annual earnings, you may be eligible for the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) from the federal government. The EITC is a refundable federal income tax credit for low-income working individuals and families. It does not affect certain welfare benefits. You must file a federal tax return to receive the EITC, even if you do not owe federal taxes. Contact the Internal Revenue Service for more information on eligibility and how to obtain necessary forms. The California Earned Income Tax Credit (California EITC) is available starting from the 2015 tax year for low-income working individuals and families. To claim the California EITC, file a California income tax return and attach form FTB 3514. Contact the Franchise Tax Board for more information on eligibility and assistance with filing. Amendments to this section apply to notices given after the effective date of the act.
